doc.after: Whaam! was purchased by the Tate Gallery in 1966.[1] In 1969, Lichtenstein donated his initial graphite-on-paper drawing Drawing for ââ'âWhaam!ââ'â, describing it as a "pencil scribble".[43] According to the Tate, Lichtenstein claimed that this drawing represented his "first visualization of Whaam! and that it was executed just before he started the painting."[44] Although he had conceived of a unified work of art on a single canvas, he made the sketch on two sheets of paper of equal sizeâmeasuring 14.9Â cm ÃÂ 30.5Â cm (5.9Â in ÃÂ 12.0Â in).[44] The painting has been displayed at Tate Modern since 2006.[45] In 2012â13, both works were included in the largest Lichtenstein retrospective that visited the Art Institute of Chicago, the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., the Tate Modern in London and the Centre Pompidou.[46][47]
